Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 97(1)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to abuse by his father; RPD denied claim citing Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) in Tirana; RAD upheld RPD decision without addressing evidence of undue hardship in Tirana
Procedural_Issue: RAD failed to address relevant evidence regarding personal circumstances affecting IFA
Evidence_Used: Evidence of family abuse, personal circumstances, and conditions in Tirana
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RAD did not consider evidence suggesting undue hardship in Tirana
Credibility_Assessment: Not directly challenged; focus was on IFA analysis
Decision_Outcome: RPD denied refugee status based on IFA; RAD upheld decision
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a different RAD panel
Decision_Rationale: RAD's failure to address key evidence rendered its IFA analysis unreasonable

Legal_Issue: Standard of Review in Credibility Assessment
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found not credible by RPD
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to sexual orientation in Algeria
Proceeding_Type: Refugee protection claim, Administrative review, Judicial review
Decision_Maker: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Federal Court
Application_Error: Alleged incorrect standard of review applied by RAD
Application_Factor: Credibility, Basis of fear, Country conditions
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed, Appeal dismissed, Judicial review dismissed

Application_Facts: Ms. Yani Meilina sought refugee status but was denied due to the RPD's internal flight alternative finding.
Procedural_Issue: The RAD applied the reasonableness standard instead of correctness for questions of central importance; plaintiff did not receive a fair appeal.
Decision_Outcome: RPD denied refugee status; RAD applied incorrect standard but error found not outcome-determinative; court granted judicial review.
Outcome: RAD's decision set aside; case remitted for re-determination by a different member.
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of RAD decision, fair hearing, recognition of refugee status
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of refugee claim with proper legal standard applied
Standard_of_Review: Correctness standard should have been applied for central legal questions; reasonableness standard applied inappropriately
Decision_Rationale: Although the error in standard of review was non-decisive, the lack of a fair appeal process warranted setting aside the decision.
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

Procedural_Issue: RAD applied incorrect standard of review
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether RAD has authority to apply reasonableness standard
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied by RPD and upheld by RAD
Outcome: RAD decision set aside, case remanded
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by RAD using correct standard
Decision_Rationale: RAD is an appellate body and must apply palpable and overriding error or hybrid standard

Victim_Status: Individual at risk due to family wealth and perceived activism
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant credible but denied claim on other grounds

Key_Evidence_Issue: Standard of review applied by RAD
Dispute_Type: Standard of review in refugee appeals
Consequences_of_Action: RAD decision set aside, remanded for redetermination

Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on extortion risk
Legal_Issue: Appropriate standard of review for RAD
Evidence_Assessment: Fear based on family wealth and conflict environment
Decision_Outcome: Claim denied by RPD, upheld by RAD
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate well-founded fear
Legal_Rule: RAD must apply palpable and overriding error standard
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of extortion and forced enlistment in Syria
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached due to procedural error

Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving nondisclosure of activities
Legal_Issue: Standard of review applied by RAD
Decision_Outcome: Claim rejected by RPD, upheld by RAD
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove eligibility for protection
Legal_Rule: RAD must substitute its decision unless bound by credibility findings
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to perceived activism and fundraising
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided due to procedural error
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee protection, which was denied by the RPD and upheld by the RAD using a reasonableness standard.
Procedural_Issue: RAD applied a reasonableness standard instead of conducting an independent review
Decision_Outcome: RPD denied refugee status; RAD initially upheld the decision
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; RAD decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Legal challenge to RAD's application of reasonableness standard
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by RAD under correct standard of review
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness vs. correctness debate; court suggests broader interpretation needed
Decision_Rationale: RAD should conduct a more comprehensive review in line with Court jurisprudence

Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies between applicant's allegations and country documentation
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to establish credibility and risk of persecution
Credibility_Factor: Plausibility of claim, consistency with country conditions, internal coherence of testimony
Legal_Rule: RAD must respect RPD's credibility findings unless demonstrable error exists
Grounds_for_Claim: Political persecution due to husband's activities
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim rejected due to lack of credible evidence
Legal_Framework: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Federal Court review
Defendant_Response: RAD upheld RPD's adverse credibility finding
Remedy_Requested: Leave and judicial review of RAD decision

Application_Error: Alleged error in rejecting application based on prior rejections and establishment
Assessment_Standard: Fair assessment of hardship and establishment
Decision_Outcome: Dismissed

Crimes.Crime_Name: False or misleading information in immigration or citizenship application

Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 14(5) of the Citizenship Act

Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in finding the applicants not credible and in concluding that Mexico could provide adequate protection?
Credibility_Assessment: The applicants' testimonies were inconsistent, implausible, and lacked detail.
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence showed Mexico's efforts to combat corruption
Legal_Provision: Credibility assessments are factual determinations requiring clear evidence of error. Applicants must prove state protection incapacity clearly and convincingly.
Basis_of_Claim: Applicants claimed refugee status due to alleged persecution after exposing corruption in Mexico.
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies and lack of detail in testimony; documentary evidence of state anti-corruption efforts
Assessment_Standard: Clear and convincing evidence required to prove state incapacity
Legal_Standard: Credibility assessments reviewed for perversity or capriciousness

Decision_Outcome: Board’s decision upheld; no error found
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, absence of perversity or capriciousness

Legal_Rule: State protection presumption applies unless rebutted by clear evidence

Key_Evidence_Considered: Documentary evidence of Mexico’s anti-corruption efforts

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant studied without valid study permit or authorization
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with conditions of stay
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Adjudication through sponsorship and judicial review process
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documentation supporting lawful study authorization
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer questioned truthfulness due to prior dishonesty and inconsistencies
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Authenticity and genuineness of marriage under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Marriage deemed not genuine based on cumulative inconsistencies and behavior

Crimes.Crime_Name: Contravention of Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Authenticity of marriage under section 4 of the Regulations
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Multiple inconsistencies in financial, travel, and familial details considered relevant
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate genuineness of marriage
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: History of dishonesty and contradictory statements affected credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Marriage not genuine if primarily for immigration advantage
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation of unreasonable decision-making by officer
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Decision grounded in factual and regulatory compliance
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial intervention to set aside decision
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 4 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with conditions of temporary resident status
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether marriage was genuine under section 4 of the Regulations
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Multiple factors including marital discrepancy, living arrangements, and interview inconsistencies evaluated
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove authenticity of marriage
Crimes.Legal_Rule: A marriage entered into primarily for status is not genuine
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA and Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Decision supported by evidence and law
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Quashing of decision and referral back
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 4 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, had a pending permanent residence application, and sought deferral of removal based on best interests of children
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Request for deferral of removal denied by removals officer
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Pending PR application, existence of Canadian-born children, mother's ability to care with social support
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal based on family ties and children's best interests
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of removal officer's decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child (short-term consideration)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably considered short-term interests of children; mother could provide care with available support; delays in applicant’s process weighed against deferral
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Removals Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 44(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after removal order issued, requested deferral based on impact on children
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national subject to enforceable removal order
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to failure to depart after removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Deferral request denied; judicial review filed
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Mother's caregiving capacity, social support network, timing of PR application
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal based on humanitarian considerations
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Limited discretion to defer removal based on exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Removals officer reasonably exercised discretion; short-term interests of children were acknowledged but did not outweigh enforcement of removal order
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Removals Officer, Canada Border Services Agency

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether removal should be deferred due to family hardship
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 40 and 44 of IRPA
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations due to family ties
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Timing of PR application after removal became enforceable
Crimes.Application_Error: Late submission of PR application after removal order enforceable
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Best interests of the child (limited scope)
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of administrative decision
Crimes.Application_Factor: Presence of Canadian-born children

Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's evidence found insufficient to establish personalized risk
Evidence_Type: Police convocation notice, articles on prisoner treatment
Basis_of_Claim: Risk of persecution in Senegal due to past incidents
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of new, compelling evidence demonstrating personal risk
Application_Factor: New evidence and personalized risk assessment
Decision_Outcome: Refusal of PRRA application and deferral requests upheld

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of credibility assessment and consideration of country conditions
Credibility_Assessment: Minor inconsistencies deemed trivial; lack of proper analysis on credibility
Evidence_Type: Threats from Taliban, letter from aid agency
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution by the Taliban in Afghanistan
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility, corroboration, delay in application, and country conditions
Application_Error: Failure to provide transparent and justified reasoning for dismissing evidence
Evidence_Ignored: Letter from aid agency without sufficient explanation
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision overturned by Federal Court

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant returned to Canada without authorization after deportation and applied for protection based on risk in Sri Lanka.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of interview and reliance on undisclosed post-application documents
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Objective evidence, pre-application country condition reports
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not central to the decision
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Protection from removal to Sri Lanka
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Quashing of PRRA decision and referral for re-determination
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness for factual and mixed questions; correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Risk analysis was reasonable; no procedural unfairness as documents were publicly available and credibility not key

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa following deportation and reapplied for protection citing risks in Sri Lanka.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Allegation of procedural unfairness due to lack of interview and use of undisclosed documents
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Publicly available country condition reports prior to application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not a central issue
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard for substantive findings; procedural fairness requirements
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No breach of procedural fairness; documents used were pre-existing and public

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Obtain Authorization to Return Under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether PRRA officer breached procedural fairness or made unreasonable determinations
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims lacked corroboration
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, country condition reports
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section of IRPA requiring authorization to re-enter after removal
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk upon return to Sri Lanka
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible, corroborated evidence of personal risk
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Pre-removal risk assessment (PRRA) and judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide sufficient evidence supporting risk claim
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found by court; applicant’s submissions were considered
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of factual findings, procedural fairness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of publicly available documents before submission date

Crimes.Violation_Type: Deportation due to serious criminal offense
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section related to serious criminality
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant deported for serious criminality, later returned without permission and filed PRRA application.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Allegation that officer failed to disclose post-application documents and ignored risk evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Country condition reports, applicant's submissions, criminal record
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Considered but not determinative; focus on objective evidence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Protection under PRRA based on risk in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness of findings, procedural fairness obligations
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably assessed risk; no procedural unfairness as documents were pre-existing and public

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making a misrepresentation to obtain immigration benefits
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Interference of persuasive Board decisions with member's discretion
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim found to be economically motivated, not based on credible fear of persecution
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 97(1) of the IRPA (misrepresentation)
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Economic motivation outweighed claims of persecution
Crimes.Application_Error: Misrepresentation through omission or false emphasis
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Correctness standard for procedural fairness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Intent to remain permanently despite claims of fear
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness for procedural fairness, reasonableness for factual findings

Crimes.Crime_Name: False statements in an immigration application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Interference of persuasive Board decisions with member's discretion
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed, no question certified
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Lack of credible fear; inconsistent intent to return to Mexico
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 97(1) of the IRPA (false statements)
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistent statements about return to Mexico
Crimes.Application_Error: False statements regarding intent and fear of return
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Credibility assessment based on consistency and plausibility
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Pattern of implausible claims and return intentions
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness for procedural fairness, reasonableness for credibility findings

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Filing of supplemental reply affidavit to introduce undertaking by immigration consultant
Crimes.Governing_Law: Federal Court Immigration and Refugee Protection Rules
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evidence only bolsters existing claims of incompetence, lacks new factual content
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to demonstrate special circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Undertaking not to practice law does not establish new misconduct
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Special circumstances required for supplemental reply affidavit
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Whether unusual, uncommon, or exceptional circumstances exist
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Incompetence and unauthorized legal practice by immigration consultant
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Undertaking by immigration consultant not to practice law
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal Court Rules and case law on affidavit supplementation
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Opposition to admission of supplemental affidavit
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavit with undertaking
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Permission to file supplemental reply affidavit
Crimes.Outcome: Denied with costs awarded against applicants
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Rule 13 of Federal Court Immigration and Refugee Rule

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Admissibility of supplemental reply affidavit regarding immigration consultant’s conduct
Crimes.Governing_Law: Federal Court Immigration and Refugee Rule 13
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evidence redundant and fails to meet threshold for exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant did not meet burden of showing exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Conduct already known; no new misconduct revealed
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Supplemental affidavits allowed only under unusual or exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Presence of unusual or exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Immigration consultant acting beyond professional scope
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: No change in outcome due to lack of prejudice
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Undertaking not to practice law by consultant
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavit with undertaking
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Rule 13

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of dismissal based on consultant conduct
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Admissibility of undertaking as evidence of misrepresentation
Crimes.Governing_Law: Federal Court Rules and standards for judicial review
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Undertaking does not prove prior misrepresentation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavit with post hoc undertaking
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Rules on admissibility of evidence in immigration judicial reviews
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Consultant misrepresented ability to provide legal services
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of exceptional circumstances and new evidence
Crimes.Application_Error: Attempting to use undertaking to prove past misconduct
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Substantial prejudice affecting fairness of proceedings
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; evidence considered but found insufficient
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Unusual or exceptional circumstances required
Crimes.Application_Factor: Timing and relevance of new evidence
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged unauthorized practice presented as legal representation

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer breached procedural fairness by not allowing the applicant to respond to doubts about document authenticity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Employment letters deemed fabricated due to inconsistencies (e.g., similar fonts, ink-jet printing, duties copied from NOC codes)
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employment letters
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Procedural fairness under immigration regulations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Use of allegedly fabricated documents to meet work experience requirements under the Federal Skilled Worker class
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credibility in submitted documents rather than insufficiency
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness does not apply if concerns arise directly from regulatory requirements or lack of credibility
Crimes.Application_Factor: Work experience documentation for Federal Skilled Worker application

Crimes.Violation_Type: Misrepresentation of work experience through fabricated employment letters
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant provided employment letters with content copied from NOC descriptions and poor-quality printing
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant for permanent residency under Federal Skilled Worker class
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of procedural fairness in not allowing response to document concerns
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence supporting claimed work experience
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Documents found to be fabricated based on inconsistencies and copying from NOC codes
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Visa application denied; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No procedural fairness breach as concerns were based on statutory credibility assessments

Legal_Issue: Credibility assessment and state protection finding in refugee claim
Outcome: Application allowed, case remitted for redetermination
Credibility_Assessment: Board's credibility assessment found patently unreasonable due to unwarranted inferences and misinterpretations
Evidence_Type: Testimony of Mr. Feradov, PIF (Personal Information Form)
Legal_Provision: Section 96 and Section 97 of IRPA regarding refugee protection
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to police targeting and religious involvement
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility of applicant's testimony and plausibility of state protection
Application_Error: Overemphasis on minor PIF omissions, ignoring plausible explanations
Assessment_Standard: Patent unreasonableness for credibility, reasonableness simpliciter for state protection
Evidence_Ignored: Plausible explanations for police targeting, context of local authorities' involvement
Legal_Standard: Standard of review: patent unreasonableness and reasonableness simpliciter
Application_Factor: Inconsistencies in dates, religious knowledge, and authority involvement
Decision_Outcome: Remitted to a differently constituted Board
Document_Fraud: Alleged inaccuracies or omissions in PIF not substantiated as fraudulent

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant misrepresented material facts in her permanent residence application
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's explanations not credible
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Contradictory statements in temporary vs. permanent residence applications
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Discrepancies in profession (lawyer vs. business manager) between applications
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Materiality of misrepresentation and potential to induce administrative error
Crimes.Application_Error: Inconsistent professional claims across applications
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation that could induce error in administration of IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Profession and employment history
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Inadmissible for two years due to misrepresentation
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False information in immigration application documents

Crimes.Crime_Name: Withholding material facts under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant withheld or misrepresented material facts in her permanent residence application
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's explanations not credible
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Discrepancies in profession and legal training between applications
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to disclose consistent professional background and legal training
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Materiality of withheld information and risk of administrative error
Crimes.Application_Error: Omission and inconsistency regarding profession and legal qualifications
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Applicant's claim of forgetfulness or agency error
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Withholding material facts that could induce error in administration of IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Professional background and legal education
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Inadmissible for two years due to withholding material facts
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Incomplete or false information in immigration forms

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board's Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) determination
Evidence_Type: Evidence of violence against new arrivals in Abuja
Legal_Provision: Section 97(1) of the IRPA, IFA test components
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution by MEND in Nigeria
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Existence of a serious possibility of danger in the proposed IFA location
Application_Error: Failure to address contradictory evidence on safety in Abuja
Assessment_Standard: Relocation must be reasonable; second branch reviewed for reasonableness
Evidence_Ignored: Reports of violence against internally displaced persons and new arrivals in Abuja
Legal_Standard: Two-part IFA test: (1) no serious possibility of persecution (correctness), (2) reasonable relocation conditions (reasonableness)
Application_Factor: Mobility rights, lack of family ties in Abuja
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision set aside, remanded to a different panel for reconsideration
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for persecution branch, reasonableness for relocation conditions

Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer breached duty of fairness or natural justice in determining sibling dependant status
Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of continuous enrollment and attendance at accredited post-secondary institution
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate unreasonableness or procedural unfairness
Credibility_Factor: Credibility of applicants' educational records and enrollment history
Legal_Rule: A 'dependant child' under IRPA must be continuously enrolled and attending full-time at an accredited post-secondary institution after age 22
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged breach of duty of fairness and natural justice by visa officer
Outcome_on_Merits: Visa officer's decision upheld as reasonable and fair
Key_Evidence_Considered: Educational enrollment records, gaps in study, nature of private home study
Defendant_Response: Visa officer applied IRPA correctly based on available evidence
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of enrollment and academic records
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to overturn visa officer's decision
Outcome: Dismissal of application; siblings not recognized as dependants

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPR Section 181 - Failure to comply with conditions of stay
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in Canada beyond the validity of their visas and applied for permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – failed to maintain legal status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to adequately consider best interests of children
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of financial documentation and police reports related to threats
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged directly; focus on completeness of submission
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Order for new assessment or reversal of decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No disproportionate hardship established; best interests of children considered but outweighed by immigration compliance

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged omission of material evidence affecting H&C claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Failure to submit updated evidence of criminal threats and financial status
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections related to H&C considerations
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Consultant’s failure to submit documents did not establish applicant dishonesty
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 25(1) IRPA – Humanitarian and Compassionate considerations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: New evidence not considered due to consultant error
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: No reasonable probability of different outcome
Crimes.Application_Error: Consultant failed to include critical documents
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None – officer was aware threats had ceased
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Natural justice and procedural fairness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Best interests of children, cessation of threats, business success

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Professional misconduct leading to failed immigration application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Impact of consultant’s failure to submit evidence on application outcome
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Regulated Canadian Immigration Consultant standards
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Missing financial records and police reports on threats
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to prove incompetence and likely different result
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: No direct allegation of fraud, but professional oversight occurred
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Advisor incompetence must be proven with clear evidence affecting outcome
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed – no proof of impact
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law principles applied to immigration decisions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Officer acted reasonably based on available information
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 25(1) IRPA
Crimes.Authority: College of Immigration and Citizenship Consultants (CIIC), Immigration Officers

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of immigration officer's decision on H&C grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Misrepresentation was present but overemphasized
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Application records, family circumstances, best interests of children
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 25 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Exemption from inadmissibility based on H&C factors
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Officer's disproportionate focus on misrepresentation
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to declare dependants initially
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Family reunification, best interests of children, integration in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under Section 25
Crimes.Application_Factor: Misrepresentation as a factor, not determinative
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for redetermination by another officer
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False or incomplete declaration in immigration application

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose dependants in immigration application
Crimes.Violation_Type: Non-disclosure of dependants in sponsorship application
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Sponsor failed to declare wife and children upon arrival
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Excluded from family class due to non-disclosure
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Compliant with residency requirements in Canada
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Omission of dependants in initial application
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Insufficient consideration of H&C factors in decision
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of immigration officer to assess H&C claims
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Family ties, duration of stay, best interests of children
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of thorough analysis of humanitarian factors
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant credible despite sponsor's omission
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent resident status based on H&C grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment of H&C application by new officer
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under Section 25
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Overemphasis on misrepresentation, neglect of family reunification and children's best interests

Application_Facts: Applicant was absent for 551 days over four years, retained business interests in Colombia, and traveled frequently.
Procedural_Issue: Appeal under s. 14(5) of Citizenship Act and s. 21 of Federal Courts Act
Evidence_Used: Physical presence records, business ties in Colombia, travel history, Koo factors assessment
Credibility_Assessment: Citizenship judge found stronger connection to Colombia
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application denied
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Centralization of mode of existence, Koo factors
Decision_Rationale: Frequent absences and significant ties to Colombia indicated that the applicant had not centralized their life in Canada.

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 11.1(b) of the former Immigration Regulations
Application_Facts: The interviewing officer was not a visa officer; personal interview by a visa officer was required but not conducted.
Procedural_Issue: Failure to conduct a mandatory personal interview by a designated visa officer
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of compliance with statutory interview requirement
Decision_Outcome: Refusal of Mr. Qin's application for permanent residence
Decision_Rationale: Statutory requirement under section 11.1(b) explicitly mandates personal interview by a visa officer; delegation to non-visa officer is not permissible

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of IAD's refusal to adjourn and dismiss the appeal
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Immigration Appeal Division decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Mental condition assessment sought but denied due to lateness and irrelevance
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed by IAD; judicial review application dismissed
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate procedural unfairness or unreasonableness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of remorse noted by IAD
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Standard of reasonableness applied to administrative decisions
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: IAD's decision found reasonable, no procedural breach
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Requested adjournment to assess mental health
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Medical evaluation (proposed)
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Adjournment and allowance of appeal on humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section related to serious criminality under IRPA

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious Criminality under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act - Serious Criminality provisions
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD decision upheld on judicial review
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Refusal to grant adjournment and dismissal of appeal
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Risk to public safety due to criminal record
Crimes.Credibility: Applicant's claims regarding disability not accepted due to late submission
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA section on serious criminality leading to inadmissibility
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Domestic criminal conduct posing societal risk

Dispute_Type: Alleged discrimination in medical care during incarceration
Legal_Issue: Did the Canadian Human Rights Commission err in dismissing Hartjes's complaint for lack of a prohibited ground of discrimination?
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evidence to establish a prohibited ground of discrimination
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: Complainant failed to provide evidence linking treatment to discrimination
Legal_Rule: s. 41(1)(c) of the Canadian Human Rights Act – Commission has discretion to refuse complaints not based on prohibited grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Allegation of inadequate medical care, lack of evidentiary link to discrimination
Legal_Framework: Federal human rights law, administrative law principles
Evidence_Type: Complaint allegations, absence of supporting evidence
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Crime_Name: Judicial Review of Visa Application Denial
Legal_Provision_Violated: Duty to inform and allow response on credibility concerns
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), principles of procedural fairness
Application_Facts: Ma family applied for permanent residency
Submitted sworn declarations and proof of private school enrollment for children
Visa Officer relied on past use of public schools to assess future demand
Residency_Compliance: Compliant with application requirements as per submissions
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged dishonesty in application not explicitly raised
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide notice and opportunity to respond on credibility
Evidence_Used: Sworn declarations by the Ma family
History of public school usage by the family
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer rejected evidence without giving applicants chance to address concerns
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility implicitly questioned without formal notice or opportunity to respond
Decision_Outcome: Visa application denied based on perceived risk of excessive demand on social services
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application by a different decision-maker
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with focus on procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Visa Officer breached duty of fairness by not explicitly informing applicants of credibility concerns
Applicants were denied opportunity to respond to adverse credibility findings
Past conduct was given undue weight over demonstrated future intent

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration Act - Departure order following failed refugee claim
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration Act, Federal Court Act s. 18.2
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed visas after refugee claims were denied; departure notices issued
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant - remained beyond visa validity and after refusal of refugee status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Motion for stay of departure notice during judicial review
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court's jurisdiction to grant stay under Federal Court Act
Evidence_Used: Alleged risk of persecution in Germany
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to demonstrate credible basis for persecution or immediate irreparable harm
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Refugee claims found not credible
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of execution of departure notice
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Interim relief allowing applicants to remain pending judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Test for granting a stay: irreparable harm, balance of convenience, public interest
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No irreparable harm established as deportation would not occur immediately; further proceedings available if they overstay

Crimes.Violation_Type: Non-compliance with immigration status post-refugee claim denial
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration Act - Failure to depart after negative refugee determination
Crimes.Governing_Law: Federal Court Act s. 18.2, Immigration Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Three young German nationals remained in Canada after refugee claims rejected and departure notices issued
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant - continued presence after refusal and issuance of departure order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Motion for leave to apply for stay of departure notice
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court’s inherent jurisdiction to issue interim stays despite lack of explicit statutory authority
Evidence_Used: Alleged risk upon return to Germany
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence showing immediate irreparable harm or likelihood of success on merits
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Refugee claims deemed lacking credibility
Crimes.Outcome: Departure notices upheld; no costs awarded
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of departure notice to complete school year
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Interim order under s. 18.2 of Federal Court Act
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Criteria for interim stay: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No irreparable harm demonstrated at this stage; court urged administrative consideration for school completion

Dispute_Type: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds exemption for permanent residence
Legal_Issue: Did the immigration officer breach the duty of fairness and make reasonable factual findings in denying the applicant's humanitarian and compassionate grounds exemption?
Evidence_Assessment: Officer relied on outdated visa applications, made contradictory findings about family support in Jamaica, failed to consider evidence of abuse and hardship
Decision_Outcome: Decision is vacated and remitted for a new hearing
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Credibility_Factor: Contradictory findings by officer regarding family support; failure to consider credible evidence of abuse and hardship
Legal_Rule: Factual findings are reviewed for reasonableness, legal test selection for correctness, procedural fairness breaches require setting aside the decision
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for factual findings, correctness for legal test selection
Grounds_for_Claim: Breach of procedural fairness, unreasonable factual findings
Key_Evidence_Considered: Outdated visa applications, evidence of abuse, hardship, family support in Jamaica
Legal_Framework: Humanitarian and Compassionate (H&C) provisions under Canadian immigration law
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (visa applications), personal affidavits (abuse, hardship)
Remedy_Requested: Vacating the decision and remitting for a new hearing before a different officer
Outcome: Application allowed, case remanded for new hearing
Legal_Provision: Section 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)

Legal_Provision_Violated: Citizenship Act - residency requirement (3 years in Canada within 4 years preceding application)
Application_Facts: Cynthia Wall spent most of her time abroad as a missionary; only 38 days of physical presence in Canada over four years; maintained significant ties to Canada including taxes, medical insurance, and family
Residency_Compliance: Not met based on physical presence; claim based on 'centralized mode of living' and Koo guidelines
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge failed to fully address the legal residency requirement; improper application of Koo's guidelines; confusion between recommendations and legal analysis
Evidence_Used: Duration of physical presence in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient analysis of residency criteria despite evidence of ties to Canada
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application initially approved by Citizenship Judge
Outcome: Appeal allowed; decision set aside; case remanded for rehearing
Relief_Sought: Minister sought overturning of citizenship approval due to incorrect legal interpretation
Remedy_Sought: Rehearing before the same Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of 'residence' under the Citizenship Act using Koo framework (combination of physical presence and centralized mode of living)
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge did not properly apply the Koo guidelines and failed to provide adequate reasoning on whether residency requirement was met

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 25(1)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa multiple times, established ties in Canada, claimed hardship due to family connections
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Refusal of humanitarian and compassionate application for permanent residency
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under subsection 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient evidence of unusual hardship; illegal employment; limited dependency on Canadian family

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of immigration officer's decision to deny H&C application
Evidence_Type: Family ties in Canada and St. Vincent
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Hardship if required to apply for permanent residency from abroad
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of unusual hardship
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to demonstrate sufficient humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under subsection 25(1)

Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Samuel overstayed his visa in Canada.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant for permanent residence or work permit
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Discrepancies between application and FOSS notes used to question credibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Board failed to raise issues during hearing, violating procedural fairness
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of the Immigration Appeal Division to assess character based on pardoned convictions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: FOSS notes, application forms, police reports
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Reliance on unverified police reports and incorrect factual assertions (e.g., son's birth year)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative assessment based on inconsistencies and omissions
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Visa denied due to character concerns
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside on judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 5 of the Criminal Records Act; procedural fairness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Improper reliance on pardoned convictions and failure to disclose key issues

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Use of pardoned convictions and unproven allegations to impugn character
Crimes.Governing_Law: Criminal Records Act, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Outcome: Decision dismissed due to procedural unfairness
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Assessed as lacking credibility due to inconsistencies in statements
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Police reports, application forms, FOSS notes
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 5 of the Criminal Records Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: False statements and omissions in immigration application
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to notify applicant of issues affecting decision
Crimes.Application_Error: Omissions and discrepancies in application versus official records
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Procedural fairness and reliability of evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Pardon under Section 5 of the Criminal Records Act
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Adverse characterization of pardoned offenses is prohibited
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inconsistencies between Mr. Samuel's account and documentation
